p.s: In the given excerpt from Disgraced, Scene 4 written by Ayad Akhtar a part of the fourth scene is displayed.
Here Amir and his nephew Abe have a discussing about a situation where Abe got involved with the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation.
Abe Hussein, who changed his name to Abe Jensen, to not be directly recognised as a muslim, comes to his uncle Amir Kapoor, who also changed his name from Abdullah, to ask him for advice.
In the beginning of the play we find out that Abe is still a part of the Muslim religion and stands by it.
In contrast to Amir, Abe is proud to be a part of the Islamic culture and you can tell that he has integrated into the American society a lot better than Amir.
In this scene some things changed compared to the beginning.
Abe tells Amir that he changed his name back to Hussein and he started wearing a Kufi again, whereas he was described as wearing typical American clothes in the first scene.
Farther in the day Abe and his Muslim friend went to Starbucks and Abe's friend started hitting on the barista.
Abe noticed right away that she wasn't into his friend but she ended up asking them about a terrorist organization.
Abe's friend said that it was founded by the US and she ended up calling the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation.
There they were interrogated about Muslim terror groups.
Abe didn't want to tell his mom and went to his uncle for advice.
He tells Amir that they brought up Abe's immigration status, which is up for renewal.
Abe explains to Emily, Amir's white American wife, that he started laughing when they said that.
he says that the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation goes into the Islamic community and looks on purpose for people who'swhose immigration status is vulnerable.
Amir ends up calling a lawyer who he had contact with during the play, to ask him for advice.
Amir left a voicemail and said to Abe that it's a good sign they let him go.

Furthermore he explains to Abe that he should maybe reconsider on which side he wants to be, taking in the fact, that the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation makes the rules and could get him deported.
When Abe makes clear, that he doesn't want to switch sides and might even want to go back to Pakistan the argument gets more heated.
Amir tries to convince his nephew that it's best to play low and act as American as possible, whereas Abe thinks that it's disgusting how he always turns on his people and his culture.
Abe ends up leaving, telling Amir that he'll handle the situation by himself.
